body:
Probably first step is to simply pick app's launcher icon. This requires no change in the api. To differentiate between the app and leak canary launcher icons, we already have "Leaks" in the launcher icon label.

Of course, allowing dev to provide alternative icon for leak canary and icon overlay can follow.
Can you think of any way to automatically default to the app launcher icon? The resource identifier could be anything.

Does this help for the purpose of leak canary? https://developer.android.com/reference/android/content/pm/PackageItemInfo.html#loadIcon(android.content.pm.PackageManager)

May be this is better https://developer.android.com/reference/android/content/pm/PackageManager#getApplicationIcon(android.content.pm.ApplicationInfo)

Source: https://stackoverflow.com/a/14417881/15139

I don't know if the above is useful considering it is runtime only.

Alternatively, could we consider going by android (rather android studio) convention? For example, Android Studio always creates projects with launcher icon as `@drawable/ic_launcher` and app name in `@string/app_name`.

This approach helps in compile time. However, this necessitates leak canary providing `ic_launcher` and `app_name` resources in the library. I think this shouldn't be an issue since leak canary already provides its own launcher icon and label. They just need to be following this convention and apps already override if they also have same resources.

If it can help, I'm always using similar approach for my apps: taking the launcher icon in grayscale and adding leak canary yellow shield icon in bottom right of it (smaller, ~25%).
The leak launcher name is the app name with ` Leaks` suffix (eg. `MyApp Leaks`).

**Edit**
Example (note that app launcher icon colors are a bit "strange" because it is for special dev flavors of such apps):

![leakcanary_launchers](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/362710/50549298-9e10c580-0c5a-11e9-8b84-819b4786512a.png)
@opatry did you manually update the asset, or using some android trickery to automatically add it?

@pyricau unfortunately, the process is very manual. I was more thinking about a desktop tool (that could eventually be integrated in the Android packaging in Gradle but it's not mandatory IMO) to automate it rather than runtime management.

issue.title: Add dynamic shortcut

repository.name: leakcanary
repository.description: A memory leak detection library for Android.

issue.body:
* The leak activity launcher icon can now be shown / hidden with a boolean resource
* On first start (API 25+) we add a dynamic shortcut to show the leak activity. It's label is based on the label of the first launcher activity in the manifest.
* Removed all the dynamic enabling / disabling of components, which was making blocking IPC calls

This enables developers to easily have one distinct icon (ie shortcut) for each app that ships LeakCanary. Fixes #1113.

body:
@frist008 we're already documented one way in the doc https://square.github.io/leakcanary/recipes/#icon-and-label : 

```
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<resources>
  <string name="leak_canary_display_activity_label">MyLeaks</string>
</resources>
```

Are you suggesting that we should add this other approach as well?
@pyricau how can we achieve that last picture that you last posted?

Nvm! I watched your Ask the Expert talk and everything was cleared out.

Great presentation
Closing, there's no API for this beyond what we've already done.
